pageSubtitle: Real communities that have transformed through UNA formation
heroText: From small neighborhood groups to established community organizations, see how UNAs have empowered communities across the country to formalize their collective efforts and create lasting impact.

testimonials.name: Maria Rodriguez
testimonials.title: Founder, East Bay Community Gardens
testimonials.quote: Forming a UNA gave our community garden network the legal structure we needed to secure grants and collaborate with the city. We went from managing 3 gardens to 12 in just two years.

testimonials.name: James Chen
testimonials.title: Organizer, Mutual Aid Network
testimonials.quote: The UNA structure allowed us to formalize our mutual aid efforts during the pandemic. We could finally open a bank account, receive larger donations, and coordinate with other organizations effectively.

testimonials.name: Dr. Aisha Patel
testimonials.title: Director, Community Health Collective
testimonials.quote: Our UNA formation process was surprisingly straightforward. Within months, we had the legal standing to partner with hospitals and apply for federal health grants. It transformed our grassroots health initiative into a recognized community resource.

testimonials.name: Carlos Morales
testimonials.title: Coordinator, Worker Cooperative Alliance
testimonials.quote: Before forming our UNA, we were just a loose network of worker cooperatives. Now we can collectively bargain for better supplier rates, share resources, and provide training programs that benefit all member co-ops.

testimonials.name: Sarah Kim
testimonials.title: Organizer, Climate Action Network
testimonials.quote: The UNA structure gave our climate activism the credibility and organizational capacity we needed. We can now coordinate large-scale environmental campaigns and work directly with policymakers.

testimonials.name: Michael Thompson
testimonials.title: Founder, Community Land Trust
testimonials.quote: Forming a UNA was the first step in our journey to create affordable housing. The legal structure allowed us to hold land collectively and develop our first community-owned housing project.
